annotation.TEXT: Time to move on to the main stages, which I was somewhat debating on which one to do first. While King Knight's stage is a bit easier and has more gold in it, Specter Knight's stage holds one of the most useful relics in the game. I can't exactly pass up the opportunity to get it as soon as possible.

We also have a slight variation of the Skeletons here. The ones wearing slightly darker armor will lose their heads after you hit them once. Afterwards, they'll walk in a straight line until they bump into a wall or fall off a ledge.

The blue ghost enemies can't be killed (not through normal means, at least). Hitting them will stun them for a few seconds, but beyond that, you'll just have to live with them as a minor annoyance for now.

This is another instance of where I did somewhat decent on the stage itself, but do horrible against the boss. Specter Knight isn't exactly difficult (especially if you abuse the Phase Locket), but he is much more mobile compared to the Black Knight. His scythe throws have a large radius, but they're easy enough to predict where they'll go, along with Specter Knight himself (since he tends to teleport to where the scythe's path will end).

Blue chests can be found in almost every stage, where upon opening it, Chester will pop out and sell you a new Relic. This one holds the Phase Locket, which is easily one of the best Relics in the entire game. Using it will make you completely invincible to everything (except for falling into a pit) for roughly 4 seconds. It's also worth noting that Shovel Knight himself will also pause for a moment on activating it (even in mid-air).

On various occasions, roaming boss fights or extra challenge stages will emerge on the overworld map. This first one isn't so much a boss (despite being depicted as a knight), but rather takes the form of a small bonus stage.

Considering I have enough for it now, I figured it'd be good to pick up the Chaos Sphere before moving on to the next stage. The Sphere itself bounces along surfaces until either a set amount of time has passed or if it falls down a pit. It doesn't seem to have any kind of damage cap on it/it never flakes out, which makes it great for dealing with enemy hordes and a few bosses.

The darkness gimmick is one that doesn't show up too often in this stage, but can prove to be troublesome if you're not willing to take your time (or haven't memorized the layout). Wait for the lightning the flash in the background, then quickly move if you're confident about moving to the layout ahead.

Yes, I did have a bit of a "Wait, what?" moment after noticing that check-point. Speaking of which, you can actually break the check-points in this game to get a bit of extra gold - though at the cost of the check-point itself becoming unusable for the rest of the stage.

The weighted platforms are the last main gimmick of this stage. They'll begin to sink if you and any other enemy or object are on them at the same time. This ties in with the new skeletons wearing golden helmets, since their heads will be left behind after you kill them. This makes for some pretty interesting puzzle solving later on, and it kind of makes me wish there was an extra challenge stage devoted to this gimmick.

Specter Knight's stage presents a few new gimmicks, a good portion of which deal with bouncing off things. This is mostly done in the form of plants that hover when you hit them, which you can then bounce up from (hitting the plant again while it's hovering will also cause it to go higher). There are also a few gravestones you can bounce off, but they tend to shatter after you leap from them.
